snippet: The measure was apparently taken in an effort to curb unrest after a week of violence, with three new stabbing attacks on Thursday.
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, in bid to calm unrest, bans politicians from visiting Temple Mount, contested site in Jerusalem's Old City; government ministers and Arab members of Parliament denounce restriction, claiming it will inflame tensions, and plan to ignore it; security is tightened, and civilians arm themselves, amid ongoing and escalating violence between Israelis and Palestinians.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Diaa Hadid from Ramallah, West Bank; Isabel Kershner and Irit Pazner Garshowitz from Jerusalem; Rami Nazzal from Bethlehem, West Bank; and Rana F. Sweis from Amman, Jordan.

lead_paragraph: The measure was apparently taken in an effort to curb unrest after a week of violence, with three new stabbing attacks on Thursday.

headline.main: Netanyahu Bars Politicians From Holy Site in Jerusalem
headline.print_headline: Netanyahu Bars Politicians From Old City Holy Site to Defuse Tensions
